learning_outcomes.description: understand the definition of and some construction techniques for balanced incomplete block designs.
understand the definitions of, and connections between, pairwise balanced designs, group divisible designs, transversal designs, orthogonal arrays and Latin squares.
understand important concepts in graph theory such as graph connectivity, extremal graphs, graph factorisation and planarity.
understand the concept of networks, flows in networks, and some algorithms used to calculate maximum flows.
appreciate some of the connections between graph theory and design theory.
communicate ideas effectively across different media.

assessments.task_description: In-semester exam held in class 10am - 11:50am on Thursday 29 August.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description: You are required to research applications of the theoretical material covered in the course, and submit either a written project or a video on this topic. Further details and assistance will be provided during the semester.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Please contact course coordinator (Darryn Bryant db@maths.uq.edu.au) for submission instructions.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description: The final examination in this course will be held during the end-of-semester examination period. It will be an in-person exam held on campus.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Weeks 1 to 13

This course has two 2-hour classes per week. These are listed as three lectures and one tutorial in UQ's timetable, but in practice each 2-hour class will be a combination of lecture and tutorial.
